title: 115_hr5362
content: The Act is titled the "IRS Information Technology Accountability Act" and focuses on the management of the Internal Revenue Service's information technology. The "IRS Information Technology Accountability Act" amends the Internal Revenue Code to establish the position of Internal Revenue Service Chief Information Officer (IRS CIO) responsible for all IRS information technology development, implementation, and maintenance. The IRS CIO is responsible for developing, implementing, and maintaining information technology for the Internal Revenue Service, ensuring its security and integration, and maintaining operational control over all IT systems. The IRS CIO is responsible for developing a multiyear strategic plan for the information technology needs of the Internal Revenue Service, advocating for those needs, and ensuring that acquired technology aligns with specified goals and requirements. The IRS CIO is responsible for developing a strategic plan for the information technology needs of the Internal Revenue Service, including performance measurements, an integrated enterprise architecture, resource considerations, and alignment with the IRS strategic plan. The plan must be reviewed and updated annually. The IRS CIO is responsible for developing a strategic plan for information technology needs, including an integrated enterprise architecture, to address new technology developments and IRS requirements. The scope of authority includes all components of the Internal Revenue Service, such as the Office of the Taxpayer Advocate. The IRS CIO is responsible for developing a strategic plan for information technology needs, including an integrated enterprise architecture. The Commissioner of Internal Revenue shall contract an independent reviewer to verify and validate implementation plans for the Customer Account Data Engine 2 and Enterprise Case Management System. The Chief Procurement Officer of the IRS must coordinate with the IRS CIO on significant information technology acquisitions, providing advance notification and regular consultation. The term "significant IRS information technology acquisitions" refers to any IRS information technology acquisition over $1,000,000 and other acquisitions identified by the IRS CIO and Chief Procurement Officer. Terms in this subsection align with those in section 7803(e) of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. The term "significant IRS information technology acquisitions" aligns with terms in section 7803(e) of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986.
